While graph isomorphisms are interesting and could be viewed as an 
additio=
nal "hidden" inefficiency, it is not necessarily desirable to 
eliminate al=
l possible functional redundancy because different 
structures that do the =
same thing represent a healthy variety of 
jumping-off points for future ex=
ploration.  That is, it's not just 
what something can do but what it might=
 be able to do in the future 
given more structure, that lends it evolution=
ary value.  Some ways of 
doing the same thing may be more extensible than =
others.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...=
> wrote:
>
> Hi
>   Checking if a new individual is an isomorph graph of
> =
on of the previous individual would be the ultimate
> answer... At least at=
 the beginning of the evolution,
> where there is few graph isomorphisms.
>=
   Sadly, checking if two graphs are isomorphs is both
> an expensive and d=
ifficult task if you don't pick a
> particular familly of graphs, like plan=
ar graphs. You
> can check if two graphs are isomorph by using a simple
> b=
acktracking algorithm, but it's slow if you need
> complex graphs...
> 
> -=
-- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> a =E9crit :
> 
> > We may address it in f=
uture experiments in order to
> > speed them up, 
> > but I probably would =
not make it the focus of a
> > publication because 
> > its solution is lik=
ely fairly straightforward, i.e.
> > not that deep in 
> > a research sense=
. Also, the problem of revisiting
> > the same points is 
> > known in stoc=
hastic algorithms already.
> > 
> > The most obvious way to address the pro=
blem is
> > simply to compare 
> > new genomes with what's come before.  Of=
 course,
> > such comparisons 
> > become increasingly expensive as the gen=
erations
> > increase, and at 
> > some point, it becomes cheaper simply to=
 evaluate
> > everyone rather 
> > than try to figure out who is a repeat. =
 Depending
> > on available 
> > resources, you can program it to look for =
duplicates
> > as long as it's 
> > computationally advantageous.  It may t=
urn out not
> > very useful for 
> > most of the run.
> > 
> > There is a p=
otential for more sophisticated
> > appraches, e.g. maybe 
> > some kind of=
 hashing scheme, but they would need to
> > promise 
> > sufficiently impre=
ssive results to justify their
> > effort.  I am not 
> > sure how much eff=
ort is justified by a 10%
> > improvement.  I am 
> > guessing work has bee=
n done on this problem before
> > outside of NEAT, 
> > but I don't know ab=
out it offhand.
> > 
> > ken
